metadata.titleEn: Moho depth and VP / VS of Dahutang
metadata.description:
The data set is mainly shown in the article https://doi.org/10.1016/j.pepi.2020.106617, which includes the distribution of the average thickness of the crust and the average Vp/Vs ratio of the crust based on the h-kappa stacking of the P-wave receiver functions on 42 stations near the Dahutang mining area in Jiangxi Province.
The dataset contains 1 file in DAT format: Dahutang_ moho_ vpvs.dat。
The data set can be used to show the Moho undulation feature of the Dahutang mining area, perspective the transverse distribution characteristics of crust and crustal wave velocity ratio in Dahutang polymetallic metallogenic area, and then discuss the difference of average composition of crust inside and outside the mining area.
metadata.instructions:
Data naming: average crustal thickness and Vp/Vs are stored in text format, and the file name is "Dahutang"_ moho_  vpvs.dat”。
Data reading mode: all ASCII files in the data set can be directly opened with text editing software. The main contents: the first column station name, the second column crustal thickness (km), the third column VP / VS, the fourth column crustal thickness estimation error, the fifth column Vp/Vs error, the sixth column station longitude, the seventh column station latitude, the third column VP / vs error, the fifth column VP / vs error, the sixth column station longitude, the seventh column station latitude, Column 8 quality control mark (1: Good; 2: Not Bad;  3: Bad)。

authorList.unitEn: Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences

literatureList.titleEn: An array based seismic image on the Dahutang deposit, South China: Insight into the mineralization

background: The Dahutang deposit is a newly discovered giant W-Cu-Mo deposit, which is located in the central part of the Jiangnan Orogen, South China. It is well accepted that this deposit is related with the magmatism in Yanshanian movement. During this period, there are widely distributed granites in South China. Ye et al. (2016) believed that the rock and ore-forming processes at Dahutang deposit are under a geodynamic setting of lithospheric thinning and extension based on the U–Pb Geochronology. This process is consistent with the large-scale tungsten ‑ tin polymetallic mineralization in the Qinhang metallogenic belt (~2000 km length, 70 – 30 km in width), South China. Fluid intrusion and oxygen fugacity are widely accepted as two important factors to affect the final mineralization in Dahutang according to the geochemical analysis. Combined with previous geochronological studies on magmatism and mineralization, the recent study showed that the multiphase magmatism and continuous accumulation of mineralization for a long period of time (151 – 130 Ma) have contributed to the formation of the giant Dahutang deposit. The Dahutang deposit is located in the central part of Jiangnan orogen, which is believed to result from the collision between the Yangtze and Cathaysia blocks during the Neoproterozoic period. Later on, this region reactivated at the Mesozoic due to the Paleo-pacific subduction. The granites outcrop in this region could be divided into two main periods, the Neoproterozoic granite and Yanshanian granite. The sedimentary rocks at Dahutang deposit include Neoproterozoic Shuangqiaoshan Group with metamorphosed turbiditic sandstone interbeds. The Neoproterozoic Jiuling biotite granodiorite is covered by Quaternary sediment and outcrop only in South Dahutang deposit.
research objective: In order to better understand the metallogenic mechanism at Dahutang region, we deployed a dense seismic array and then performed the seismic image to get the deep structure. In order to reveal the deep structure and better understand the mineralization in Dahutang region, we deployed a dense array cutting across the deposit. The possible mechanism for the formation of the Dahutang deposit is proposed based on previous frameworks and our new result.
challenges: However, the deep structure of Dahutang deposit is still unknown, and the reason for such a rare 20 m.y. long-lived multiphase magmatism and successive mineralization is puzzled. There are several large scale geophysical investigations in South China, including active seismic profile, ambient noise tomography, receiver function, density inversion from gravity and seismic constraints, and joint inversion of receiver function and gravity anomaly, but they have low resolution at Dahutang district. Even Yao et al. (2013b) performed the gravity explosion on the distribution of intrusive rocks at shallow depth; there are no geophysical observations with special attention on the deep structure beneath Dahutang deposit.
methods: We deployed a dense seismic array and then performed the seismic image to get the deep structure, including the ambient noise tomography, receiver function calculation, H- κ stacking and joint inversion of receiver function and surface wave dispersion. We deployed a linear dense seismic array in Oct 2018, with the trend oriented in NW-SE direction that cut across the main geological units. The P wave receiver function and short period group dispersion were measured based on this data. We follow the common data procedure developed by Bensen et al. (2007) to calculate cross-correlations. Fast Marching Surface Tomography (FMST) is applied to invert the mixed path Rayleigh wave group velocity. CPS330 program gives a linear algorithm to do the S-wave velocity inversion. P wave receiver-function image and H –κ stacking technique provide insightful tools to analyze discontinuities.
dataset: This array includes 50 three-component short-period portable seismographs (QS-05A, with 120 Hz-10 s bandwidth; marked by the light blue triangles in Fig. 1 b), and the distance interval is ~2 km. We finally got the data from 47 stations, and the average duration of the seismic stations is 14 days. The long period dispersion data comes from an ambient noise tomography of China, which involves more than 2000 stations and the resolution of group velocity in South China is 50 km.
findings: The seismic image and gravity anomaly show a low velocity in the upper crust, high velocity in the middle-lower crust, relatively high Vp/Vs ratio, and low gravity anomaly beneath the Dahutang deposit. These features may indicate the process of mineralization: under the context of lithospheric extension and thinning in the Late Mesozoic, there are some magma underplating and melting the lower crust. The hot melts migrated upward and differentiated, the dense component cooled in the middle-lower crust to form the high velocity zones. The light component intruded into the Neoproterozoic granite and formed the Mesozoic granite, providing the heat and material source for the further enrichment of tungsten ‑ copper polymetallic ore.

Verification.Question: Is a dense seismic array a valid method for collecting data to understand deep structures related to mineralization?
Can the H-κ stacking method be used to accurately analyze discontinuities in geological structures?
Does the deployment of short-period portable seismographs provide reliable data for seismic imaging in the Dahutang region?

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection method is utilized to analyze the deep structure of the Dahutang region?
What challenges are faced in obtaining high-resolution geophysical observations of the Dahutang deposit?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to study the deep structure beneath a mineral deposit area?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to study the deep structure beneath a mineral deposit area involves deploying a dense seismic array to perform seismic imaging, which includes techniques such as ambient noise tomography, receiver function calculation, H-κ stacking, and joint inversion of receiver function and surface wave dispersion.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when investigating the deep structure of a mineral deposit?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge faced when investigating the deep structure of a mineral deposit is the lack of high-resolution geophysical observations specifically focused on the deep structure beneath the deposit, despite large-scale geophysical investigations like active seismic profiles and joint inversion techniques being conducted in the region.

Feature Specification.Question: What features of the geological structure are identified through joint inversion techniques in seismic studies?
Feature Specification.Answer: low velocity in the upper crust, high velocity in the middle-lower crust, relatively high Vp/Vs ratio, low gravity anomaly

Feature Specification.Question: What properties of the crust are studied using the H-κ stacking method in seismic data analysis?
Feature Specification.Answer: average crustal thickness, average crustal velocity ratio (Vp/Vs)

Quantification.Question: How many seismic stations were deployed in the dense array for data collection in the Dahutang region?
What is the average duration of data collection at each seismic station in the dense array deployed for the Dahutang region?
What is the distance interval between the seismic stations in the dense array deployed across the Dahutang deposit?

Definition.Question: What does 'P wave receiver function' mean in the context of seismic data collection?
Definition.Answer: In the context of seismic data collection, 'P wave receiver function' refers to a technique used to analyze the seismic waves generated by earthquakes to infer the structure of the Earth's crust and upper mantle. It involves calculating the response of the Earth's crust to P waves, which are primary or compressional waves, to identify discontinuities and variations in seismic velocity.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for seismic imaging using a dense array compare to those used in ambient noise tomography for understanding the deep structure of mineral deposits?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection methods for seismic imaging using a dense array involve deploying a linear dense seismic array with three-component short-period portable seismographs to measure P wave receiver function and short-period group dispersion. In contrast, ambient noise tomography involves using a broader network of stations to capture long period dispersion data, with the resolution of group velocity being significantly larger. The dense array provides higher resolution for analyzing local deep structures, while ambient noise tomography offers a broader regional perspective.

Comparison.Question: How does the resolution of data collected from a dense seismic array compare to that from previous large-scale geophysical investigations in the same region?
Comparison.Answer: The resolution of data collected from a dense seismic array is higher than that from previous large-scale geophysical investigations, which include methods like active seismic profile and ambient noise tomography. The dense array, with its closely spaced seismographs, offers detailed insights into local deep structures, while large-scale investigations provide broader, less detailed regional data. This increased resolution allows for more precise analysis of the mineral deposit's deep structure, which was not possible with previous lower-resolution methods.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn about subsurface geological structures from the application of P wave receiver function and ambient noise tomography in a dataset?
Interpretation.Answer: The application of P wave receiver function and ambient noise tomography can reveal low velocity zones in the upper crust and high velocity zones in the middle-lower crust, indicating processes such as magma underplating, melting, and differentiation. These insights suggest the movement of hot melts upward, cooling of dense components, and intrusion of lighter components, which are crucial for understanding mineralization processes.

Interpretation.Question: How can the deployment of a dense seismic array across geological units contribute to our understanding of mineralization in a region?
Interpretation.Answer: Deploying a dense seismic array can provide detailed seismic images of the deep structure beneath mineral deposits. This approach allows for high-resolution data collection that can reveal velocity anomalies and structural discontinuities, offering insights into the processes such as lithospheric extension, magma underplating, and the formation of ore deposits.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in obtaining high-resolution geophysical data in regions like Dahutang?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in obtaining high-resolution geophysical data in regions like Dahutang are due to the low resolution of existing geophysical investigations at the district level, despite several large-scale studies in South China. The absence of focused geophysical observations on the deep structure beneath the Dahutang deposit also contributes to these challenges.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to deploy dense seismic arrays when investigating the deep structure of mineral-rich regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Deploying dense seismic arrays is necessary to reveal the deep structure and better understand the mineralization in regions like Dahutang. These arrays provide detailed seismic imaging, which helps in analyzing discontinuities and understanding the geodynamic settings that contribute to mineralization processes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the complexity in understanding the multiphase magmatism and mineralization over long periods in areas like Dahutang?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complexity arises from the unknown deep structure and the rare occurrence of 20 million years long-lived multiphase magmatism and successive mineralization. Although there are existing geophysical investigations, they lack the resolution and focus needed to unravel these complex geological processes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of deploying a dense seismic array across a mineral deposit area in terms of understanding the deep structure?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Deploying a dense seismic array can result in detailed seismic imaging, revealing the deep structure of the region. This may provide insights into low and high velocity zones, which could indicate processes such as magma underplating and mineralization under lithospheric extension and thinning conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of deploying a dense seismic array in the Dahutang region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of deploying a dense seismic array in the Dahutang region is to better understand the metallogenic mechanism by obtaining a seismic image to reveal the deep structure. This aids in comprehending the mineralization processes and proposing mechanisms for the formation of the Dahutang deposit based on the new seismic data and previous frameworks.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to perform joint inversion of receiver function and surface wave dispersion in geophysical studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Performing joint inversion of receiver function and surface wave dispersion is important because it provides comprehensive insights into the subsurface structure, offering high-resolution data that can help identify features such as discontinuities. This approach is crucial for understanding the deep structure beneath complex geological areas like the Dahutang deposit.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in deploying a dense seismic array to obtain seismic imagery for deep structure analysis in geological research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To deploy a dense seismic array for deep structure analysis, a linear dense seismic array is set up with seismographs arranged in a specified orientation, such as NW-SE, to intersect main geological units. The array includes multiple three-component short-period portable seismographs, and data is collected over a set duration. Techniques like ambient noise tomography, receiver function calculation, H-κ stacking, and joint inversion of receiver function and surface wave dispersion are used to process the data and produce seismic images.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements and instruments enabled the deployment of a dense seismic array for studying the deep structure of mineralization regions?
Enablement.Answer: The deployment of a dense seismic array was enabled by advancements in seismic instruments, such as the use of three-component short-period portable seismographs (QS-05A, with 120 Hz-10 s bandwidth), which allowed for detailed data collection across multiple stations with a distance interval of approximately 2 km.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or factors led to the need for deploying a dense seismic array across geological units in mineral-rich regions?
Enablement.Answer: The need for deploying a dense seismic array was driven by the unknown deep structure of mineral-rich regions and the lack of high-resolution geophysical observations. Existing large-scale investigations had low resolution, prompting the deployment to better understand the multiphase magmatism and mineralization processes.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dense seismic array be expected to yield detailed insights into the deep structure beneath a mineral deposit?
Expectation.Answer: A dense seismic array captures high-resolution data that enables detailed seismic imaging, which can reveal deep structural features such as discontinuities, velocity anomalies, and layering beneath a mineral deposit. This is achieved through techniques like ambient noise tomography and receiver function analysis, which are enhanced by the dense spatial coverage of the array.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons for the low resolution of existing geophysical investigations at certain districts, even with several large-scale studies conducted?
Expectation.Answer: Existing geophysical investigations might have low resolution due to factors like insufficient station density, limited duration of data collection, or the methods used, which may not be sensitive enough to detect smaller scale features or deep structures. Additionally, the complexity of geological formations and the specific focus of previous studies might not have been tailored to the unique characteristics of certain districts.

Expectation.Question: Why might the average duration of seismic station deployment be crucial for capturing comprehensive data in seismological studies?
Expectation.Answer: The average duration of seismic station deployment is crucial because it affects the ability to capture a wide range of seismic events and ambient noise data necessary for accurate imaging and velocity analysis. Longer durations allow for the collection of more comprehensive datasets, which improve the reliability and resolution of the resulting seismic images and the interpretation of deep crustal structures.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using dense seismic arrays for understanding the deep structure and mineralization processes in geological regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Dense seismic arrays are effective for understanding deep structures and mineralization processes because they provide high-resolution seismic images and insights into the crust's velocity and density variations, as shown by the deployment around the Dahutang deposit.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways might the challenges of low-resolution geophysical investigations in specific districts be addressed to improve the accuracy of geological studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges of low-resolution geophysical investigations can be addressed by deploying more localized and dense seismic arrays, as well as integrating multiple methods like ambient noise tomography and receiver function calculations to enhance the resolution and accuracy of geological studies, particularly in regions like the Dahutang district.

Judgmental.Question: What potential advancements or refinements in data collection methods could be explored to better differentiate crustal components and mineralization features in complex geological settings?
Judgmental.Answer: Advancements in data collection methods could include the use of joint inversion techniques combining receiver function and surface wave dispersion data, as well as developments in seismic imaging technologies to better differentiate crustal components and mineralization features in complex settings like those observed in the Dahutang region.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the deployment of a dense seismic array contributes to revealing the deep structure in the Dahutang region.
Assertion.Answer: The deployment of a dense seismic array allows researchers to perform seismic imaging techniques such as ambient noise tomography, receiver function calculation, and H-κ stacking. These methods help to analyze and visualize the deep geological structures, providing insights into the mineralization processes at the Dahutang deposit.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why the deep structure of the Dahutang deposit remains unknown despite several large-scale geophysical investigations.
Assertion.Answer: Despite numerous geophysical investigations in South China, including active seismic profiles and ambient noise tomography, the resolution of these methods has been low in the Dahutang district. This has left the deep structure beneath the Dahutang deposit largely unexplored, necessitating more precise and focused studies like the deployment of dense seismic arrays.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how the P wave receiver function and short period group dispersion measurements are processed to yield useful data.
Assertion.Answer: The P wave receiver function and short period group dispersion measurements are processed using established procedures, such as those developed by Bensen et al., to calculate cross-correlations. These data processing techniques, along with Fast Marching Surface Tomography and S-wave velocity inversion, facilitate the creation of seismic images that reveal discontinuities and other significant geological features.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the challenges faced in achieving high-resolution geophysical observations in complex geological regions and suggest potential solutions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The main challenge in achieving high-resolution geophysical observations in complex regions like the Dahutang district is the low resolution of existing large-scale geophysical investigations. While techniques such as active seismic profiles, ambient noise tomography, receiver function, density inversion from gravity, and joint inversion of receiver function and gravity anomaly have been employed, they often lack sufficient resolution. One potential solution is the deployment of a dense seismic array, as was done in Dahutang, to obtain detailed seismic images and better understand the deep structures. This approach can provide more precise data on crustal composition and mineralization processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the potential for expanding dataset collection to cover broader geophysical parameters and its implications for understanding mineralization in geological regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Expanding dataset collection to include broader geophysical parameters can significantly enhance the understanding of mineralization processes. In the Dahutang region, the dataset is primarily focused on seismic data obtained through a dense array. To broaden this understanding, additional data such as gravity, magnetic, and electromagnetic measurements could be integrated. This would allow for a more comprehensive view of the subsurface features, helping to identify variations in crustal composition and the processes leading to mineralization. The integration of these datasets could also improve the resolution of models and provide insights into the geodynamic settings influencing mineral formation.
